To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.
div.p: Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

div.head: RED SEA LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.

THURSDAY, JANUARY 5, 1905.

div.head: RAILWAYS IN TOE LEVANT.
div.p: It will not be many yearn before the isolation of the Egyptian railway system becomes a thing of the past. The Khedive's railway is gradually creeping towards the Tripolitan frontier, while the northward march of the Cape to Cairo line is always moving Railhead nearer and nearer. Meanwhile, the develop- ment of the railway communications in Syria is proceeding apace and for several months past the French Embassy at Constantinople has been

div.head: Sunlight
div.p: A great economiser and saver of time, health, and strength.
Laundry worries went out of woman's life when Sunlight Soap came into it.
It is the purest Soap going.
Soap

negotiating with the Ports on the subject of the construction of a line from Damascus to Hamah, and from Hamah to Aleppo, by a French company. The concession has at last been granted, in spite of the efforts which the Germans made to render the project abortive. The proposed line is not a long one, but its oommercial importance will be very marked. Aleppo is a great trading centre, and the sur- rounding conntry is very rich. Hitherto.no line has connected the town with the Syrian coast, and the new railway will therefore afford a valuable outlet for the agricul- tural produce and manufactures of the dis- trict. The French are all the more delighted at the succcess of M. Constans in obtaining the concessions for the French company, since the Germans have done their utmost at Con- stantinople to include Aleppo in the coontry to be served by the Bagdad railway, and to induce the Saltan to forbid the construction of any other railway near the town. The traffic of the district, instead of going by the Bagdad line, will now be tapped by the more natural way of Beyrout. In granting the concession the Sultan said that he did so in order that the ancient and traditional friendship between turkey and France might receive a new con- firmation. It is evident that some suspicions have entered the Sultan's mind that the Kaiaer’s attitude towards him is not altogether disinterested, at least so far as relates to Asia Minor. The linking of the Syrian and Egyptian railway systems will Inevitably come to pass and few engineering difficulties attend the con- struction of a line by the short desert route via Kantara and Gaza to the Jaffa-Jerusalem line. It may not be many years before there will be through communioation from Cairo to Calais via Constantinople and Vienna.

div.head: RUSSIAN SURRENDER
JAPANESE CONDITIONS
25,000 PRISONERS.
STOESSEL ASKS FORGIVENESS.
div.p: Tokio, January 4.

The terms of the surrender are contained in eleven articles. The garrison and officials are prisoners. All the forts and war materials are to be transferred to the Japanese. If the Rus- sians destroy anything, the negotiations are to be annulled, and Japan will then be free to take action. The Russians are to give plans of the fortifications and mines. Considering the gallant resistance made by the place, the Rus- sian officers are to be permitted to keep their swords and private property. On giving their parole, they will be allowed to return to Russia. The rank and file in uniform, with their portable property, are to assemble, under their respective officers, in a place indicated by the Japanese. The sanitary corps and the accountants are to be retained in order to assist in caring for the sick and wounded.

Russian officers who have reached Chifu state that Stoessel's army was originally 35,000 of whom 11,000 have been killed, and 16,000 are sick or wounded. There were 8,000 in the forts, 2,000 of whom were unable to fight. During the siege, 265% of the garrison were “hors do combat." This remarkable fact is due to the wounded having returned to the front
(Reuter.)
Chi-Fu, January 4.
The Japanese have made 25,000 prisoners at Arthur.
(Havas.)
St. Petersburg, January 4.
General Stoessel, in telegraphing to the Tsar his formal surrender, says:—“Great Sovereign, forgive us, we have done all that was humanly possible. Judge us, but be merciful.”
(Reuter.)
Tokio, January 4.
The Tsar has cabled to General Stoessel allowing the officers the option between giving their parole and imprisonment.
(Reuter.)

div.head: SIGNIFICANT MOVE BY TSAR.
REVIEWS ABANDONED.
div.p: St. Petersburg, January 4.
The Tsar has cancelled all reviews in the provinces. He returns to St Petersburg im- mediately.
(Reuter.)

div.head: AN ERRAND OF MERCY.
BRITISH RELIEF FOR THE WOUNDED.
div.p: Wei-hai-wei, January 4.

H.M. cruiser “Andromeda” has left here for Port Arthur. She carried 80 tons of medical supplies and other comforts for the sick and wounded, including 350 beds and 100,000 lbs. of provisions. The cargo was rushed on board during the night following the granting of permission for the errand of mercy.
(Reuter.)

div.head: THE MUSCAT AFFAIR.
APPOINTMENT OF ARBITRATOR.
div.p: The Hague, January 4.
The Dutch Government has appointed the Deputy M. Lohman as arbitrator in connection with the Anglo-French difference with reference to Muscat. The affair is to be settled by the Hague Tribunal.
(Reuter.)

div.head: HUNGARIAN DIET.
DISSOLVED BY THE EMPEROR.
div.p: Budapest, January 4.
The Emperor has dissolved the Diet. The ceremony passed undisturbed. The Opposition was absent.
(Reuter.)
Budapest, January 4.
The Speech from the Throne closing the session states that the situation necessitates an appeal to the electors.
(Havas)

div.head: HELLENIC CHAMBER.
DATE OF GENERAL ELECTION.
div.p: Athens, January 4.
The Chamber of Deputies has been dissolved.
The general election will take place on March 5 next.
(Havas)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: The Branch Office of Messrs. Thos. Cook A Son (Egypt), Ltd., opposite the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, is now open.
Bubonic Plaque.—To-day's bulletin records a fresh case at Toukh, where a patient died in hospital and another was discharged as cured.
Business Notice.—Mr. Edward Nathan has ceased to be a member of the firm of B. Nathan and Co., Alexandria. Mr. Victor F. Naggiar has also retired from the business.
The End of a 'Bull'.—Our Zifta Correspon- dent writes under yesterday’s date announc- ing that a Greek had hanged himself in the Mit Ghamr district owing to his great cotton losses.
The British Turbine Yacht “Emerald,'' about whose movements during the passage through the Canal of the Baltic Fleet there was so much speculation, arrived at Alexandria yesterday from Port Said.
Motor Transport Company. — We hear that a motor transport company has Just been founded in Cairo under the auspices of Rostovitz Bey, George Nungovich Bey, and Messrs. Lonkas and Lonkaitis.

The Italian Consulate—The lease of the present habitation of the Italian Consulate at Cairo, in the Ismalia quarter, has been renew- ed, the scheme for removing the consulate to Kasr-el-Nil or Shoubra having been postponed for the time being.

Verdi Theatre, Cairo.—Part of the Italian operatic company at the Verdi have resolved to stay on and try their fortune at the theatre. We congratulate them on their decision and hope that they will have no cause to repent. The Cairo public should do their best to help them.

Siemens-Schuckert-Werke—The firm's ge- neral agency of Cairo, up to the present under the direction of Messrs. Orwnsein & Koppel and Mr. Gustav Grob, has been handed over exclusively to the latter. Mr. Gustav Grobb, E.E., is now the sole representative of the house for Egypt and the Sudan.

Fatal Collapse of a Roof. — At an early hour this morning the roof of an old and delapidated tenement in Sisters-street, Alex- andria, collapsed over a bedroom while the occupants, Mr. and Mrs. Baila, were still in bed. The former was awakened by a rumbling noise, and believing that robbers had entered the house, rushed out of the room. When he returned he found his wife had been buried in the ruins and asphyxiated. The police are engaged in removing the body from the debris.

Children's Savings Bank.—On tho 16th inst, the Egyptian Post Office scheme for Childrens’ Savings Banks will come into force. For the present the area of its operations will be confined to Cairo, Alexandria, and Port-Said. Each child desiring to deposit will be furnished with a booklet. When five milliemes are collected a stamp will be bought and put in the booklet and when the sum of one shilling (10 stamps of P.T. 1/2) is attained, the amount will be deposited in the Post Office Savings bank

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive has gone to Edfina from Mon- tazah.
His Highness will attend Friday prayers to- morrow at Montazah mosque.

div.head: RAMLEH ELECTRIC RAILWAY
THE PUBLIC AGITATION.
div.p: The Theatre at Bacos station was filled yesterday evening by a crowd of about 200 persons for the purpose of discussing the new tariff instituted by the board of directors of the Alexandria and Ramleh Railway Com- pany. The meeting began at about 8.30 p.m., when the chairman, Mr. Benjamin Arbib, made a statement as to the attitude which the board of directois had taken up towards the committee of Ramlehites, who had en- deavoured to set their grievances before them. He said that all the inhabitants of Ramleh should demand the maintenance of the former season-tickct system. This was the one aud only programme which the com- mittee would ask the board to take into con- sideration, as although there were many questions pending between the population of Ramleh and the company, these did not ne- cessarily call for immediate settlement.
Mr. Halil Zenia then spoke in Arabic and expressed himself as being in hearty agreement with the opinions of the chairman.
Many other speakers followed and gavo vont to a number of various and conflicting sugges- tions for settling the question at issue.

Chevalier Rouci, chairman of the Tenants' Defence Committee, then rose and, in an im- passioned oration in Italian, announced that the cause of Ramleh was also the cause of the committee over which he presided.

Mr. Geo. B. Alderson shortly afterwards ar- rived on the scene and was greeted with acclamation. A scene of great enthusiasm followed, and afterwards Mr. Alderson’s scheme for settling the problem was given forth to the meeting in Italian by Mr. Quintavalle.
The meeting broke up at 11 p.m. All the persons attending the meeting refused to pay their fares both on going and coming to the meeting. The employes of the Company did not make any fuss.

div.head: THIS MORNING'S DEVELOPMENTS.
div.p: Great excitement prevailed on the line this morning. The meeting last night was the subject of universal discussion by the passen- gers. As a large number persisted in refusing to pay the fare the company was obliged to seek for the assistanoe of the Alexandria City Police. Fifteen policemen were placed at the service of the company in order to draw up “proces-verbaux" in cases of non-payment of fares. Some angry Ramlehites tried to rush through the cordon of police and a scene of considerable excitement ensued. But the majority of them accepted the situation with an air of peaceful resignation and agreed to pay tho fares. The police were stationed at the gate of the station and asked each passen- ger arriving from Ramleh for his or her ticket

As we go to press we learn that matters are proceeding quietly and that no serious distur- bance has as yet taken place. We understand, however, that the agitators do not intend to let things resume their normal course unless the directors give way, and that other mani festations against the new system will take place shortly.

The committee of Ramlehites will meet the directors to-day, in order to ascertain from them if they intend to bow to the wishes of the inhabitants. Another general public meeting of Ramlehites will be held on Saturday evening next at 9 o’clock at the Bacos Theatre.

div.head: “G.B." AND THE SITUATION.
div.p: Mr. Geo. B. Alderson writes:—The company have right on their side, to a certain extent. I have noticed how travellers look at the "oommissaires" and say “Abonne.” They may have been, as myself, an abonne for 40 years, but the commissaire may have been employed 40 hours only and knows not the “Abonne" of 40 years. I have also noticed how tra- vellers take tickets to Ibrahimieh and go past it, and if asked, pay the difference. Control, under these conditions, is difficult for the company. Their right to annul season tickets without giving a “quid proquo” I dispute—and should wish to have it brought before tribunals to decide. But I suggest, to meet all parties amicably, that the company issue to all residents or householders who wish to be abonnes and have a right at old price ‘‘carnets’’ special for 3, 6, 9, or 12 months, calculated at 4 journeys per day. Each "carnet" to be for 3, 6, 9, or 12 months, paid in advance and every ticket dated and personal, but each quarter the "carnet” to be returned to the company, and any tickets unusrd to be accept- ed back by the company at 50% on its value.

div.head: THE HEDJAZ RAILWAY.
div.p: Marshal Kiazim Pasha has sent the follow- ing report to the Grand Vizier:—The Maan- El-Hassa section has been completed, and the military engineers are now working on the embankment beyond Maan, the rails being laid as the line is built. The line has also been finished between kilometres 490 and 520. Important levelling work is now being done on the Haiffa section. Tunnel No. 1 is in course of construction, and No. 2 is making favor- able progress.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL DUES.
REPORTED REDUCTION.
(From our own Correspondent)
div.p: Port-Said, Thursday.

Although as yet not officially admitted, I have it on reliable authority that it has been decided in Paris to reduce the Canal dues from 8 fes. 50 cms. per ton to 8 fes. Bridge deck dues will still be charged.
The date on which the reduction will come into force is not yet known.
On the 31st ulto. 13 vessels psssed through the Canal, viz., 7 British, 1 Austrian, 1 French, 1 Norwegian, 1 German, 2 Dutch; the re- ceipts for the day being frs. 852,274.76.

The returns for the year 1904 show that during the twelve months ended December 31, 4,257 ships entered the Canal, the total amount received in dues being 114,875,154.68 frs, an increase of frs 12,292,113.41 over the preceding year. In 1903 the number of ships passing through the canal was 3,775. The year just closed, therefore, shows an increase in the total, as compared with 1903, of 482 vessels, a considerable advance on last year’s figures, which only showed an excess of 67 when com- pared with 1902. If we take the number of ships returned during the past six years as having used the Canal the great increase in number during 1904 beoomes still more marked, the respective totals being:-

div.head: BIBBY LINE
div.p: The steamer "Worcestershire" having proved herself such a complete success, and commend- ed herself to the many passengers by her on her maiden voyage, Messrs. Bibby Brothers Co., have placed with Messrs. Harland & Wolff of Belfast, an order for a sister ship, to be called the "Herefordshire,” the construction of which is now being proceeded with. With the advent of this steamer, the “Lancashire" and “Yorkshire," which have in the past done such good service in the line, will drop out as soon as possible—indeed they will not again appear in the lists for the busy season, either outwards or homewards. The Bibby Line will therefore in future be composed entirely of twin screw steamers of the most up-to-date type. Outward passengers via Marseilles will be glad to know that it has been arranged that they can now leave London a day later, say on the Thursday morning, embarkation at Marseilles being fixed for noon on Friday. This extension of time will not alter the time at which the steamers will arrive in the East, which will be as here- tofore.

div.head: EXPEDITION VIA KHARTOUM.
div.p: Mr. J. J. Harrison left London last week for Khartoum on his second expedition on the Congo. He intends to travel along the west side, bordering on the Nile and Ituri district He hopes to be able to secure an okapi in the forest region. Mr. Harrison has obtained leave in Brussels to bring home some pigmies.

div.head: SUDAN EXPLORATION CAPITAL
div.p: An extraordinary general meeting of the Sudan Exploration, Limited, was held last week for the purpose of considering a resolu- tion for increasing the capital to £100,000, by the creation of 80,000 new shares of 10s. each, to rank for dividend and in all other respects pari passu with the existing shares of the company. Mr. Edgar Anderson, who presided, moved the resolution, and it was agreed to.

div.head: SLEEPING SICKNESS IN THE SUDAN.
div.p: A short time ago we published an article by the director of the Gordon College Laboratories on Trypanosomiasis in the Sudan, which was reproduced from a London medical paper.

We are requested to state that some portions of the artiole appear to have been inaccurately printed. We may point out that it has not been proved that trypanosomiasis in man, i.e., tree sleeping sickness spread by Glossina palpalis, exists in the Sudan.

div.head: EXPORT OF GUM ARABIC.
div.p: During the month of November last, 868,243 kilos of gum arabic, valued at L.E. 19,412, were exported from Egypt. In the same month of 1903 the exports were 730,738 kilos, of the value of L.E. 16,426, showing an increase this year 132,505 kilos, value L.E. 2,986.

From the 1st January to 30th November 1904, the exports show increases of 1,532,316 kilos in weight and of L.E. 31,144 in amount as compared with 1903, the respective figures being as follows:- 1904, 9,370,440 killos, value L.E. 210,843; 1903, 7,838,124 kilos, value L.E. 179,699.

Of the above, the export to England and her Mediterranean possessions was 1,737,422 kilos, value L.E. 39,091; Germany, 1,559,925 kilos, value L.E. 35,099; Austria-Hungary, 664,921 kilos, value L.E. 14958; France and Algeria, 2,555,552 kilos, value L.E. 57,474; Italy, 260,548 kilos, value L.E. 5,849; Turkey, 12,303 kilos, value L.E. 269; America, 1,380,571 kilos, value L.E. 31,062., and to other countries 1,200,198 kilos, value L.E 27,044.

div.head: PILGRIMAGE REGULATIONS
TEXT OF GOVERNMENT NOTE.
div.p: The following is a translation of ths Note issued yesterday by the Egyptian Govern- ment:-
The different measures taken by the Egyptian Government with regard to persons desiring to make the pilgrimage to the Holy Places have been prompted by two motives:

1. To insure tho greatest freedom and facilities to all who wish to fulfil this sacred duty, while guarding them from all useless expenditure and from the dangers of the journey, and giving them all the medical attention that their health during the pilgrim- age may necessitate.

2. To control the return of the pilgrims with a view to the avoidance of epidemics, which are always possible. In this connection the circular addressed to all moudirs and governors on November 16, 1904, deserves to be noted. This circular states that every Egyptian has the right to make the pilgrimage whenever his means allow of it, and that if he fears to travel alone the Government gives him the opportunity of accompanying the Mehtmal, being anxious to make the pilgrimage as easy as possible.

Last year the same measures were taken and 600 pilgrims asked to be allowed to accompany the Mahmal. This year 1,614 had inscribed their names on the list of those desirous to accompany the Mahmal before it was closed.

Those who have already left for the Hedjaz admit that the oooditions imposed on the pilgrims who accompany the Mahmal are pecuniarily the most advantageous, not to mention the advantages of military protection and medical assistance.

If the pilgrim travels alone he must make a deposit of P.T. 156 at the Moudirieh whence he draws his passport, of which P.T. 100 represents the rations given him by the Go- vernment in the quarantine camp at Tor and P.T. 56 the quarantine expenses. If, as is usually the case, he travels 3rd class, he will have to pay some LE 5 for his return ticket on the Khedivial mail boat and once in the Hedjaz will have to find a camel. Even if one camel is taken by two pilgrims there is no chance of getting one for less than LE 18 or 20 even for the journey from Jeddah to Mecca and Arafat and thence to Yambo. Taking this cause as a test the 3rd class pilgrim will have to pay:- Deposit... ...................... P.T. 156 Return ticket. .................... „ 500 Minimum half share in one camel. „ 900 P.T. 1,586 without counting the alms and bakhshish which he will be obliged to pay.

If, on the other hand, he travels with the Mahmal he will only have to pay. Deposit...................... P.T. 156 Transport and return.......... „ 300 Half share in a camel......... „ 675 Unforeseen expenses... ... ... „ 69 P.T. 1,200
But in reality this is only a deposit, and if the camel hire does not reach the fixed price and there are no unforeseen expenses the sur- plus will be returned to him.

So far from profiting the Government, these measures are decidedly costly owing to the necessary arrangements with the Khedivial Mail S. S. Co. by the guarantee of a mini- mum number of pilgrims in return for the reduction of fares.

This year, moreover, the Government has not hesitated to bring the escort of the Mahmal up to 400 men, this increase of 280 men involving an additional expenditure of LE 5,000. In spite of this the obligatory depos- its are not be increased.

Only the deposits of the lowest class cover all the expenses. As for the others, if the price of a camel is the same as last year the Government will pay the difference itself to convince the pilgrims of its anxiety for their comfort and welfare.

div.head: CAIRO ZOOLOGICAL GARDENS.
div.p: On Sunday, 8th inst., in honor of the Khe- dive’s acceesion to the throne, the Egyptian Army Infrnatry Band, being required in Cairo, will not play at QGhizieh. The drums and fifes of the Ghizieh Boys’ Band will play in the Zoological Gardens from 3 to 5 p.m. on that day.

Among the additions to the Zoological Gordons during December, 1904, were a grivet monkey, presented by Lieut. A. Sargent, Army Ordnance Department, a Soemmerring’s gazelle and a Hedjaz sheep born in the gardens, and the following animals pur chased :—two marmosets, one of the white and one of the black whiskered race, a greater mealy amazon-parrot, a Levaillant’s amazon-parrot, two white-shafted francolins from Massowah, several beautiful little wax- bills and weaver birds from Tropical Africa, and some flamingoes from Lake Menzalah.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Meseageries Maritimes SS. ‘Sydney" arrived at Marseilles from Alexandria yester- day at 9 a.m.
The Ellerman SS. "Britannia" arrived to- day from Fiume.
The Canard SS "Brescia" arrived at Liver- pool on Tuesday afternoon.
The Khedivial Mail SS “El Kahira" will leave Alexandria on Sunday for Jaffa, Caiffa, Beyrout, Tripoli, Mersina, Alexandretta, Lar- naos, Limassol and Port Said.

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET.
DEPARTURE INDEFINITELY POSTPONED.
(From our own Correspondent.)
div.p: Port Said, Thursday.
The departure of the Russian fleet from Ceuta Bay has been indefinitely postponed.

div.head: OUR ROYAL VISITORS
div.p: On the conclusion of the Duke and Duchess of Connaught's stay in Cairo, they will proced by rail to Luxor and will then go on in the steamer “Isis” to Wady Halfa and will continue their voyage to Khartoum by rail. The arrange- ments for the Royal journey to the Sudan ere in the capable hands of Nungovich Bey.

We understand that it is not the Crown Prince of Sweden and Norway, but his esdest son, H. R H. Prince Gustaf Adolf; who is coming to Egypt on a visit His Royal Highness is expected in Cairo on the 16th inst and will put up at Shepheard's Hotel. His Royal Highness is accompaniad by Baron de Ralamb, his aide-de-camp.

div.head: CAIRO FETE COMMITTEE
LAST NIGHTS BALL
div.p: The ball given at Shepheard's last night was a huge success, and reflected the greatest credit- on the organising powers of the Cairo Fete Com- mittee. Nearly all the leading members of Cairo society were present, also a large number of visitors, and the scene in the ball-room was a most brilliant one, especially during the cotillon, which began on the stroke of midnight and was led by Mme Cottaui and Mr. De Martino.

We believe that this is the first occasion on which all the principal hotels have combined in organising a fete on such a large scale, and the success of the experiment is of good augury for the future.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H H. the Maharajah of Khapurtala and suite are expected in Cairo early in March. Large apartments have been reserved at the Ghe- rireh Palace for his Highness and suite.
The Duke and Duchess of Devonshire and Mr. and Mrs. MacGuire are leaving Marseilles on the 20th inst, and are expeoted at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, on the 25th.
Sir Ernest Cassell, Lord and Lady Howes, the Hon. Mr. and Mrs. Colebrooks, with a party of friends, are leaving Marseilles on the 27th inst and are expected at the Savoy on the 3rd February.
Lord and Lady Cromer have postponed their journey up-river till the beginning of February.
Mr. Vincent Corbett will leave for Khartoum to-morrow. He will be absent for three or four weeks.
Count Teziersky and suite are expected back at the Bristol, Cairo, from their shooting expedition in the Zudan, at the mid of the month.

Sir Colin Scott-Moncrieff, hit wife, and two daughters left England on Tuesday last for Egypt, where they will pass four months. Sir Colin has taken a dahabieh, and the late Under Secretary of State for Public Works is looking forward to re-visiting many scenes of his former labors.

Lady Magheramorne, who is to marry Lord Cromer's nephew, Mr. Hugo Baring, has been a widow not quite two yean. She was the second of the five beautiful daughters of the eighth Earl of Shaftesbury, of whom the other four married the Earl of Mar and Kellie, Sir George Warrendcr, Mr. George Allsopp, end Mr. Levett. Lady Evelyn Ashley married the second Baron Magheramorne, Sir James Doa- glss McGarel-Hogg, in 1889, when she was twenty-four, and has one charming daughter who is now in her fifteenth year. Lady Maghe- ramorne, though well known and very popular in society, is still better known in county Antrim, for country life appeals very strongly to her.

Mr. Hugo Baring is the youngest brother of Lord Revelstoke. He is twenty-eight, end was a lieutenant in the 4th Hussars. He served with some distinction in the Transvasl War, and still carries the scars of that campaign.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Wynn (sister of Lord Newborough) to Commander Cuthbert Chapman, is fixed for February 1 at the pictu- resque Chapel Royal, Savoy, where Lord and Lady Newborough themselves were married four years ago. After the wedding Commander Chapman and his bride will leave for Italy and Egypt.
The rumour as to Saba Pasha’s retirement appears to have arisen in some mysterious way from Journalistic speculations as to Kaimakam Borton Bey's future post.
The Sanitary Administration has authorised Mr. Augustus Newton to practice as a phar- macist in Egypt.

div.head: GUNNY BAG MARKET
Shrager Bros Calcutta Market Report
div.p: London, December 22.

The market has rated quioter this week, a* speculators have shown more inclination to; take tbsir profits, which has rnado the position rather-easier all round, but mill sellers con- tinue ss firm as ever.

Export euquirios are scarce, and for suchi buying as had to be done for Burmah and the Straits full prices were paid, the goods generally! being required for prompt shipment, while forj forward deliveries prioee show a decline and! some inter-bsssar businoas resulted. At the close tho position is steadier, and sellers are not quite so keen to go on, unless at an advance.

HESSIANS are dull for near but steady for forward, but there is no improvement to report in the demand, and tho absence of orders further weakensdho position for this and next month, holders Bring anxious to clear their! several parcels.
Tho Gunny marked, will be closed from the: 34th instant to the 2nd prox. inclusive, on account of the Christmas and New Yew holi- days and we shall in oonsequeuoe issue no report next week.

div.head: aboukir lands.
IMPORTANT LEGAL JUDGMENT.
div.p: Last week a judgment of considerable im- portance vu giveu by the Mixed Court of let Instance at Alexandria. Aboukir ia one of the best localities iu the neighbourhood of Alexan- dria. The exquisitely bracing air, the pictures- que surroundingMnd the historical associations run dor this spot the most attractive -on the whole of the Egyptian sea-board.and it should develop iu course of time into an Egyptian Brighton. But the one and only obstacle lies in the fact that Prinoe Omar Pasha Toussoun ban set his heart on becoming the solo landlord at Aboukir and does his best to discourage private. persons from acquiring land. An English lady, the wife of Mr. Richmond, Sub- Director of the Aboukir Land Company, was eager to build a bungalow on the seashore at Aboukir for her invalid mother, whose health had greatly improved in the summer of 1903 by a sojourn at Aboukir, when she rented Mr. Crafton's house there. Mrs. Richmond set to work to find a suitable plot of land and at last discovered a pretty little spot of half a foddan ot land, which the owoer was willing to sell provided Pnnoe Omar Paaha Toussoun did not pre-empt, llis Highness was ap- proached, but was proof against all overtures. Consequently Mrs. Richmond arranged with the landlord to lease the land for ninety yoars and built a residence there. Prinoe Omar thereupon brought an aotion against Mrs. Richmond and was non-suited. The following is the text of the judgment

Attendu quel‘art.5 du difcretsur la preemp- tion, dont les tenure sont plus restraints en- core que ccux do Part. 96 c.c, n'accorde 1c droit de preemption que contra oelui qui a acquis par le moyen d'uno vente; qu'il en reason k Evidence quo oe droit no aaureit fitre iuvoque contra un simple locataire qui n'aoquiort aucun droit sur la chose.

Attendu que S. A. le Prinoe Omar Pacha Toussoun soutiont, il ret vrai, que le bail de 90 ans pretendumeut oonaenti par Abdalla Mous- tafa a la Dmo Richmond serait un oontrat fictii masquant uno convention de vonte.

Mais attendu qu'il lui inoombeiait do prouver le bien fond5 de cette pretention; que, s'il ret vrai que le Sr. Alderson, pi re de la dame Richmond; avert tout d'abord Pintention d'acbetcr Pimmeuble dont s'agit et a fait oon- naltre cetto intention au Prince, qui a declare vouloir precmpter le cas Ccheant, rien ne prouve que le dit sieur Alderson ait porsisti .U.n cette intention et ait rtallcmeut voolu, soit it son profit, soit k oelui do sa fille, deveuir acqudreur de Pimmeuble, malgri la oertitude qu 'il avaitde le voir passer, par voie de prtamp- tion entre Ire mains du Prinoe; qu'il ret bien plus vraisemblable qu'il a voulu, oommo il lo declare, s'assurer d'uno ft^on oortaine la jouissance du terrain en question et tauter toute possibility do preemption en oontractani reellcment un simple bail it long tonne : que pared oontrat ne renferme en lui-mimo neu quo do Iigitime ot de Ifgal, aucun texte do lui no defendant A un propnt-taire, malt re absolu de sa chose, de la louer mime pour un terme de 90 ans, pour le prix qui lui oonvient ot dans les conditions qu’il lui plait de oonsentir, en accordant parexemplo au locataire un droit do passage sur un autre terrain de sa pro- , priiUS; quo Ire baux it long terme sont au oon- traire reconnus par Part 740 code civil; qu’il importe peu que lo prince so trouve ainai privd d’un moyen d’acquirir lui-mime Pimmeuble; que lo propriitaire n’avait aucuno obligation d’agir de maniire it lui assurer cette acquisi- tion ; qu’il feudrait, pour justifier le droit de preemption du demaudeur, qu’il fflt dtaontn*, qu'uno vente effective aureit nfellemeut ere conclue et quo le bail dont s'agit ne serait qu’un acte nitmile fait en fraudo de oe droit du demandeur; que pareillo demonstration n'ret nullement flute et que la demande doit done etre rejetta

Par ore motifs : Oul le miniature Public en son avis et sta- tuant publiquement et oontradictoirement de clare le demandeur mal fonde en son action, Pen debouto avee condamnation anx depens, bonorairre de l’avocat dre defendeurs taxes k P.T. 300.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
INPANT MORTALITY.
div.p: To na Editor or in* Eamux Gaxittx.

Sir,—In perusing Mr. Lang Anderson's illu- minative paper upon “land values,” -which recently appeared in your columns, one of the topics to which he alludes especially attracted my attention. He told us that, roughly speak- ing, one-third of the children of native parents die within twelve months of their birth, and that another third die before they reach five yean of age. Mr. Irang Anderson's reputation for accuracy stands far too high for him to have allowed himself to make such allegations without satisfying himself previously as to the truth of his statements. They most therefore bo accepted as prima facie correct. Now, 8ir, I think the public is entitled to know whether this deplorable state of affaire is of xeoent date or of ancient origin, and, in either eveut, for how much longer it is to be allowed to con- tinue unchecked. I bold it to be the paramount duty of the Government forth with toinveatigate the causes contributing to this (terrible waste of human life, and, having ascertained them, to devise effective moasares for arresting the shocking ravages death is making amongst the infant population.

div.head: A NEW SUEZ CANAL.
THE QUESTION OF MONOPOLY.
div.p: In connection with Sir Theodore Angier'a auctions that Mr. Gladstone “bad to oonfeas ho »as wrong” in his assumptions that the Suer Canal Company possessed a monopoly on the Isthmua of Sure, it is interesting to note mIuii was said in Parliament on that subject sit,. M. Ferdinand do Lesseps, the President of the Sore Canal Company, had voluntarily renounced the advantages of the Agreement signed between the British Government and the Sure Canal Company, on July 11, 1663. The Agreement had been presented for ratifi- cation to the Houso of Commons, but the oppo- sition to it was so great that Mr. Gladstone felt that even his groat infloenoe would not suffice to cany it through. In his letter to the Prime Minister M. de Lesseps said among other things :—

“In the interests of general peace, and in the interests of the Franoo-English Alliance, indis- pensable lor the civilisation of the world, I beg you not to consider yourself bound towards the shipowners and towards myself by the terms of tho Agreement we have signed."

The withdrawal of that Agreement was the signal tor a recrudesoenoe of the agitation iu England against the Sure Canal Company, and in favour of cutting what was oalled "a British Canal." The British Government was publicly urged to use its influence in Egypt to constrain the Khedive to grant a concession for a second Canal across the Isthmus to an English com- pany. Replying, in the House of Commons, to a question put to him on that point on July 12, 1883, Mr. Gladstone said :—

“We ooold not try to obtain those conces- sions, for the simple reason that the Khedive has not tho power to grant them. M. do Les- seps possesses an exclusive right of canal- cutting in so far as the Isthmus of Sow is concerned."

This assertion was repeated in the House of Lords a fow days later—on July 17—by Lord Granville ; and on August 12 the House of Commons, having demanded the opinion of the Solicitor General, received his declarations, which ooncludcd with tho following words :—

“I profit by this opportunity to state that tho legal advice which the Government has received has been not' only that of tho legal officers, but also that of the Lord Chancellor." Mr. Childers, the Chancellor of the Ex- chequer, had stated in the Houso of Commons on July 17 :—
“We believed that tho exclusive power possessed by the Company prevented us from constructing a new Canal unless M. de Lesseps should have forfeited his rights.”
Having been requeate 1 to defino what ho meant by “tho exclusivo privilege of the Sure Canal Company," Mr. Gladstone did so in these words -—
“A power given to prevent othor persons piercing tho Isthmua ol Sure by a Canal."

Peraeveringly intent on obtaining a con- cession for a second Sure Canal, the advo- cates of tho project suggested that the ex- clusive privilege granted to M. de Lesseps might oease, on his death. Mr. Gladstone, however, remarked that a privilege granted for ninety-nine years to a man already past middle ago was certainly not destined to expire with him, but that it would pass to the oompany formed by him.

A little later on, tho nowspapors having insinuated that Mr. Gladstone had changed his opinion, tho Prime Minister replied to a question put to him in tho House of Commons that his previous declarations were definitive, rinoe they had been inscribed in the Minutes of Parliament Then, addressing the Chancellor of the Exchequer, a member of Parliament inquired whether it was true that, to a deputa- tion of shipowners concerning M. de Lesseps’s monopoly, be had declared that her Majesty's Government had arrived at the conclusion that M. de Lesseps or hiS company had an exclusive right of a water-way across tho Isthmus of Sues. To this Mr. Childers replied :—
“I employed words in the sense indicated by tbo hon. member, and 1 see no reason to deviate from that declaration."

These quotations are quite sufficient to demonstrate that the British Government frankly admitted the exclusive character of tho right of canal-cutting conferred on M. de Lesseps and his oompany by his oonoeesion. It was alter this that M. de Lesseps came to England and negotiated with tho shipowners, with tho result that the two parties agreed to what is called “the London programme” It provided, as everyone knows, for the rather contradictory desiderata of the reduction ol canal duos and the improvement of the water- way, and also for tho admission of seven British shipowners or merchants on the Board of Directors of the Suez Canal Company.

div.head: ACCESSION DAY. KHEDIVIAL RECEPTION.
div.p: On the occasion of tho anniversary of his accession to tho Throne, H.H. the Khedive will hold a deception on Sunday, 8th insl., at Abdeen Palace, when viaiton will observe the following boon and order :

At 8.30 a.m.—T.H. the Ppnoee of the Kho- divial Family ; the Ulema ; tho President of the Council of Ministers and'the Ministers; the Financial Adviser; the Judicial Adviser; the Advisers at the Ministry of the Interior and of Public Works.

At 10 a.m.—The former Presidents of the Counoil of Ministers, Ministers, Sirdars, Grand Masters of Ceremonies, Chiefs of the Khedivial Cabinet, Chief Aides-do-Camp, Director* of the Khedivial Khassa, Directors General of Wakfo, Under Secretaries of State, Directors General of tho Daira Sanieh, Domains Administrators, and Administrators of the Roil ways, Telegraphs, and Port of Alexandria, unofficial civil and military personages having tho rank of Lews or Oulaf 8inf Sani and upwards ; offioers of the Navy and Army on pension or on the retired list, of tho rank of Kaimakam or Miralai; civil Beys not in office, of the rank of Moutemau and Sanieh.
At 10.30a.m.—The Diplomatic and Consular Corps,

At 10.45 a.m.—‘Tho Publio Debt Commis- sioners; the Director General and Controllers of the Daira Sanieh ; the Administrators of State Domains, tho Administrators of the Railways, Telegraphs and the Port of Alex- andria.
At 11.15 a.m.—The field offioers of the Army of Occupation ; the Clergy ; the Mixed Magistracy ; the Native Magistracy.
This reception is reserved to persons resident in Cairo.

Decorations will be worn. Naval and Mili- tary officers will be in fall dress uniform; natives and foreigner* of rank or exorcising duties obliging them to wear a special uniform, will wear those uniforms. Native and Euro- pean officials whose rank or dutios do not oblige them to wear a uniform will appear in atom- bouline, with black trousers. Non-official Europ- eans and those without rank will wear dress suits. Natives who woar national oostnme will bo received in that oostnme.

The oiril officials to be admitted to this reception are those holding, at least, tho rank of cubdirector or an equivalent rank, and those holding, at least, the rank ot Sanieh or Kaimakam (military) and magistrates appoint- ed by docroo.
Names may be registered for Her Highnees the Khedivah at the Bureau of Ceremonies of the Harem, beside the Gate of Honor of Abdeen Palace.
H. H. the Khedivah will also hold a recep- tion at Abdeen on Sunday, when she will r- ooivo as follows
From 9 to 11 JO a.m.—'The Princesses of the Khedivial Pamily and native ladies. From 3.30 to 4.16 p.m.—European ladies. At 4-20 p.m.—The wives of members of the Corps Diplomatique.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY. EGYPTIAN STATE RAILWAYS INSTITUTE.
div.p: Five gold medals and five gold^entred silver mortals have been kindly presented by Mr. F. H. Trevithick, president of the above institute, for a 6 a-side Association football competition to be hold on the ground of the institute at Cairo, during the Beyram holiday, oommencing on February 15. This oompeti- tion will be open to teams of bona-fide member* of rooogniaed football clubs in Egypt, also to company and unit teams of the Army ol Occupation. Tho entrance fee is P.T. 20 per team. This, together with the names of the proposed players and reserves, must be sent to Mr. Wm. Greenhalgh, Football Secretary, Railway Institute, Cairo, not later than Feb- ruary 1. The above conditions will be strietiy enforced, and the oommittee reserve the right to refuse any entry

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
